title: How to find out which literary agents are seeking new authors - Quora

response.answer_text: I'm a couple years out of that end of the game, but when I was doing serious agent hunting,  the sense that I got was that nearly all agents are doing their level best to elude most new authors.  Dealing with new authors, preparing their manuscripts, preparing the ground with editors and then actually selling it is just too much work to want to bother seeking out new authors.  But having said that,  most are suckers for a supurbly written pitch letter.   I suspect nearly everyone in that miserable business is a two-headed dragon.  If you write something that is just too good, they will want to see it. Then, of course the true nature of their two-headedness manifests itself.  They'll eagerly ask for the MS, at which point it joins a massive pile of manuscripts and they won't remember anything about the sweet little mating dance you and she performed over the query, because several months will have passed and all she'll want is an excuse to reject it.  any excuse will do.   But that's another story....

Look at the submission areas on their web-sites, it will clearly state if they are open to submissions and the format you need to adhere to when submitting. Alternatively, identify agents most suited to your genre, ring them up and ask them. Success comes with focus, determination and initiative, and some luck of course. never, never, never give up as Winston Churchill said.
